awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Eye evolution in Sarsielloidea (Crustacea: Ostracoda): an integrative approach based on phylogenetics, developmental genetics, behavior and optics.
awd_abstract_narration:
Within a single species males and females can differ dramatically.  This is known as sexual dimorphism.  This project aims at uncovering the evolution, development, and ecological purpose of a radical sexual dimorphism in a group of crustaceans known as "seed shrimp" or ostracods.  While males do not contain additional genetic information compared to females (they have no Y chromosome), they are able to generate large image-forming eyes whereas females have only rudimentary eyes that cannot form an image.  This project will combine developmental biology, bioinformatics, phylogenetics and next-generation sequencing to uncover the genetic differences in males and females in various species showing different levels of sexual dimorphism.  Using these data and data collected from ostracods worldwide, the researchers will also be able to elucidate the evolutionary history of this dimorphism.  In addition, the researchers will examine the behavioral aspects underlying this dimorphism by testing whether males require image-forming eyes to have a high mating success rate.  

The broader impacts of this project are multifold:  First, this project will contribute new understanding regarding the genetics and evolution of sexual dimorphism in an ecological context.  Second, this project provides research opportunities for researchers at many levels including pre-health and pre-grad undergraduates, masters students, post-doctoral researchers, and junior and senior faculty.  The researchers have strong records of service in broadening participation of under-represented groups in science and preliminary work has already provided research opportunities for several individuals from underrepresented groups including the project director.  Third, this research will strengthen international collaboration with a Swedish research group.  Finally, this research will provide key additional data regarding the evolution of eyes, a subject which has long fascinated the public, allowing the researchers to contribute to public education via outreach.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This collaborative study between PI-Rivera (University of the Pacific) and Co-PI Oakley (UCSB) addressed the evolution and development of an extreme sexual dimorphism in ostracod crustaceans. These ostracods exhibit radical sexual dimorphism of their lateral eyes – males have large image-forming eyes while females have only small eye-spots.  Image-forming eyes are are metabolically expensive yet they often confer huge fitness benefits.  We addressed three related questions. First, what are the genetic underpinnings of the developmental decision to make or suppress eyes? In other words how is the sexual dimorphism coded genetically? We found that about one third of the candidate eye development genes we examined were expressed differentially in male and female developing eyes.  All of these genes were also expressed during early embryogenesis (before eyes begin to form), suggesting that they are key developmental genes that are redeployed to build image-forming eyes in males only.

Second, we tested the ecological significance of the image-forming eyes of males. We found from experimental evidence that females spend less time in the water column and are less likely to be eaten by fish predators.  Males, on the other hand, spend more time in the water column (seeking females who probably only mate once) where their predators live.  Blindfolded males were eaten by fish at a higher rate than mock-blindfolded males.  This, with additional visual acuity data, suggests that the image forming eyes in males are adapted to evade predators.  Females and juveniles living primarily in the sand are invisible to water column predators and appear to suppress the development of these costly sensory organs. This provides a rare demonstration of a sexual dimorphism that is not caused directly by sexual selection.

Third, we asked whether sexual dimorphism of eyes evolved more than once in the superfamily. Here, we scored 131 morphological characters (including eye dimorphism) from 238 species. We also sequenced transcriptomes from 30 species. We found that sexual dimorphism evolved more than once in the superfamily. For our collections, we deposited specimens in the Australian Museum and the Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History. We published a description of 2 new species and have nearly completed description of another new species. Publishing transcriptomes of ostracods led to new collaborations, when colleagues discovered genes of interest in the data, including hemocyanins. We included ostracod opsin genes sequenced from this project in taxonomically broader analyses. We published (including postdoc, PhD and MSc student, and undergraduate co-authors; often as first authors) 11 research papers related to this grant. PI-Rivera additionally published two reviews on the subject with MSc students as first authors.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to training 2 postdoctoral researchers, 3 PhD students, 4 MSc students (three theses completed, one in progress) we have also used this funding to train over 35 undergraduate researchers broadly in developmental biology, phylogenetics, molecular biology, and organismal biology.  Importantly, most students were given the opportunity to help design and troubleshoot their own project, work on a team, and present at national conferences.  The vast majority of students stayed in the PI or Co-PI lab for the 30 week school year.  Many stayed for two or more years (a few even spent nearly their entire college career in one of the labs), giving them the time and space to have an authentic research experience that they could apply to life after college.

University of the Pacific students hosted a local elementary school field trip, wrote and gave a developmental biology presentation to San Joaquin Valley middle school and high school students, and made educational materials related to ostracodology that we are currently editing for dissemination. Additionally, PI-Rivera gave lectures for undergraduates and MSc students on this project at Pacific as well as at Cal State Stanislaus and the University of San Francisco. The grant facilitated interaction between labs of two different sized Universities. We made many bioinformatics tools available in the Galaxy platform in a set of phylogenetics tools called Osiris, which are available on the public repository github.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2016
Modified by: Ajna Rivera
